Quoting pisharath_k <pisharath_k@...>:

> Thanks for your suggestions everyone (please see my original mail 
> attached below).
> 
> But the problem I am having is this - the classes are complex, hence 
> constructing classes with test data (so I can check against the data 
> read from file) is very cumbersome. 

I agree that it is cumbersome, but I don't see what alternate you have IF you 
want to test every part of the every class.

If you only care about certain fields, then you can always assertEquals() on 
the fields you care about. This assumes that those values are available through 
the public interface, of course.

> Also, with equals() method I 
> cannot know which data member in the class actually caused a mis-
> match, since I assert only at the class level.

This is why you implement toString() to show the value of the object, so that 
you can see which fields are different.

> This is why I am thinking what to do... hope this clarifies the 
> problem. 

It sounds like you're simply trying to test something that's big (not 
necessarily difficult) and time-consuming. If you want to test the whole thing, 
then nothing you try will be simpler than implementing equals() and following 
our suggestions. If you don't mind testing less than the whole thing, then you 
can check individual fields that you read from XML against known values.

Of course, if you have the power to do so, simplify the object model!
